bibl.title: Letter from Lillie W. Franck to Jefferson Randolph Kean, June 17, 1946

div1.p: Franck asks Kean to correct the enclosed copy of his answers to earlier questions, sign his name, and mail it to Hench. Kean adds a note to Hench, dated June 19, 1946, in which he recalls a portrait which was done of himself.

div1.head: Letter from Lillie W. Franck to Jefferson Randolph Kean, June 17, 1946
div1.p:
Here is the original copy of questions and answers of
Wednesday evening June 5th. You recall Dr. Hench wishes you to
correct this copy, and sign your name, and mail it to him. I am
enclosing envelope ready for mailing.
Please fill in the name of the painter on page 2 Q. 66.

Hope to send you the answers you dictated to me on May 25th
very soon. But do not hold this set, but please mail them to Dr.
Hehch as soon as you have gone over them. I have mailed him two
carbon copies.

As to the name of the artist who painted my
portrait for the sala in the Secreteria de Sanidad,
I have spent a lot of time looking it up in my diaries-
I cannot say it was entirely time wasted, because I became
so interested in old memories that I had great pleasure tho.
I lost many hours. I found in D. VII p. 78 that my cousin
John Coolidge of the State Dept. who happened to be in Havana,
work with me “to the meeting of the Nat. Sanitary Board when
crayon portraits of Gov. Magoon, Dr. Findlay and myself
were unveiled in the sala of the Board, with the usual lau-
datory speeches”- March 7th 1908- This is evidently not the por-
trait in oil which you are interested in, and which I am
sure was painted later- Of course the Nat. San. Board lost
its importance when it was replaced by the Sec. de Sanidad
over
Ac
K
y Beneficencia- Whether the Secy of the new Cabinet
position has the same sala as the Old Board
I do not know- My somewhat vague recollection
is that when the American Public Health Assn-
had their annual meeting in Havana in Dec 1911
Gen. Gorgas and I were guests of the Nation and
one afternoon of the meeting was taken up in a
formal meeting of the Assn and the Cuban State Secre-
teria de Sanidad y Beneficia- in which our portraits
were unveiled “with the usual laudatory speeches”
much to the disjust of members of the U. S. P. H. Assn
who wanted to get through with their business and
catch the steamer home- My portrait was probably
a copy of the Crayon above mentioned- If I find
anything more I will let you know- if not it is no great
matter- I hope that you will get something of val-
ue out of these pages- There does'nt seem to me
to be much of value in them-
